editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: Printed at London by 〈◊〉 for William Aspley, and are to be sold 〈…〉 shop in Paul's churchyard.
Amico svo Candido et Cordato, Johannes Marston musarum Alumnus
Asperam hanc svam thaliam D. D.

div.head: To the reader.
div.p: I am an ill orator; and in truth, use to indite more honestly then eloquently, for 'tis my custom to speak as I think, and write as I speak.

In plainness therefore understand, that in some things I have willingly erred, as in supposing a Duke of Genoa, and in taking names different from that city's families: for which some may wittily accuse me, but my defence shall be as honest, as many reproofs unto me have been most malicious. Since (I heartily protest) was my care to write so far from reasonable offence, that even strangers, in whose state I laid my scene, should not from thence draw any disgrace to any, dead or living. Yet in despite of my endeavours, I understand, some have been most unadvisedly overcunning in misinterpreting me, and with subtlety (As deep as hell) have maliciously spread ill rumours, which springing from themselves, might to themselves have heavily returned. Surely I desire to satisfy every firm spirit, who in all his actions, proposeth to himself no more ends than God and virtue do, whose intentions are always simple: to such I protest,
that with my free understanding, I have not glanced at disgrace of any, but of those, whose unquiet studies labour innovation, contempt of holy policy, reverent comely superiority, and established unity: for the rest of my supposed tartness, I fear not, but unto every worthy mind 'twill be approved so general and honest, as may modestly pass with the freedom of a satire. I would fain leave the paper; only one thing afflicts me, to think that scenes invented, merely to be spoken, should be inforcively published to be read, and that the least hurt I can receive, is to do myself the wrong. But since others otherwise would do me more, the least inconvenience is to be accepted. I have myself therefore set forth this comedy; but so, that my enforced absence must much rely upon the printers discretion: but I shall entreat, slight errors in orthography may be as slightly o'erpassed; and that the unhandsome shape which this trifle in reading presents, may be pardoned, for the pleasure it once afforded you, when it was presented with the soul of lively action.
div.closer: Me mea sequentur fata. I. m.

list.item: Giovanni Altofronto disguised Malevole sometime Duke of Genoa.
Mendozo a minion to the Duchess of Pietro Jacomo.
Ferneze a young courtier, and enamoured on the Duchess.
Ferrardo a minion to Duke Pietro Jacomo.
Aurelia Duchess to Duke Piet: Jacomo.

Emilia
Beanchatwo ladies attending the Duchess.

div.head: Sce. prima.
div.stage: The vilest out of tune music being heard.

sp.speaker: Bilioso.
sp.p: Why how now? are ye mad? or drunk? or both? or what?

sp.speaker: Prae●.
sp.p: Are ye building Babylon there?

sp.speaker: Bilioso
sp.p: Here's a noise in court ▪ you think you are in a tavern, do you not?

sp.speaker: Prap
sp.p: You think you are in a brothel house do you not? This room is ill scented.
So; perfume; perfume; some upon me I pray thee: the Duke is upon instant entrance; so, make place there.

div.head: Scaena secunda.
div.stage: Enter the Duke Pietro, Ferrardo, count Equato, count Celso before, and guerrino.

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.p: Where breath's that music?

sp.speaker: Bilioso.
sp.p: The discord rather than the music is heard from the malcontent Malevoles 〈◊〉 ●

sp.speaker: Ferrar.
sp.p: Malevole.

sp.speaker: Male.
sp.p: out of his chamber.yaugh, godaman what dost thou there: Dukes Ganymede junces jealous of thy long stockings: shadow of a woman, what wouldst weasel? thou lamb a court: what dost thou bleat for? A you smooth chinned catamite.

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.p: Come down thou rugged cur, and snarl here, I give thy dogged sullenness free liberty: trot about and bespurtle whom thou pleasest.

sp.speaker: Malevole.
sp.p: I'll come among you, you goatish blooded toderers, as gum into taffeta, to fret, to fret: I'll fall like a sponge into water to suck up; to suck up. Howle again. I'll pray, and come to you.

sp.speaker: Pietr●.
sp.p: This Malevole is one of the most prodigious affections that ever conversed with nature; a man or rather a monster; more discontent than Lucifer when he was thrust out of the presence, his appetite is unsatiable as the grave; as far from any content as from heaven, his highest delight is to procure others vexation, and therein he thinks he truly serves heaven; for 'tis his position, whosoever in this earth can be contented is a slave and damned; therefore does he afflict all in that to which they are most affected; the elements struggle within him; his own soul is at variance; his speech is halter-worthy at all hours; I like him faith, he gives good intelligence to my spirit, makes me understand those weaknesses which others flattery palliate: hark they sing.

div.head: Scaena Tertia.
div.p: See he comes; now shall you hear the extremity of a malcontent: he is as free as air; he blows over every man. And sir whence come you now?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: From the public place of much dissimulation;

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: What didst there?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Talk with a usurer; take up at interest.

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: I wonder what religion thou art?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Of a soldier's religion.

sp.speaker: Pietr.
sp.p: And what dost thou think makes most infidels now?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Sects, sects, I have seen seeming piety change her robe so oft, that sure none but some arch-devil can shape her a new petticoat.

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.p: Of a religious policy.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: But damnation on a politic religion.

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.p: But what's the common news abroad Malevole, thou dog'st rumor still.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Common news? why common words are, God save ye, fare ye well: common actions, flattery and cozenage: common things, women and cuckolds: and how does my little Ferrard: a ye lecherous animal, my little ferret, he goes sucking up and down the palace into every hen's nest like a weasel: and to what dost thou addict thy time to now, more than to those antique painted drabs that are still affected of young courtiers, flattery, pride and venery.

sp.speaker: Ferrard.
sp.p: I study languages: who dost think to be the best linguist of our age?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Phew, the devil let him possess thee, he'll teach thee to speak all languages, most readily and strangely, and great reason marry, he's travelled greatly i'the world; and is everywhere .

sp.speaker: Ferrard.
sp.p: Save ith' court.

sp.speaker: M●l..
sp.p: I save ith' court: and how does my old muckhill overspread with fresh snow ▪ thou half a man half a goat,to Bilioso. all a beast: how does thy young wife old huddle?

sp.speaker: Bili●.
sp.p: Out you improvident rascal.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Do, kick thou hugely horned old Duke's ox, good master Make-pleece.

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.p: How dost thou live nowadays Malevole?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Why like the knight s. Patrick Penlobran's, with killing a spider's for my lady's monkey.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: How dost spend the night, I here thou never sleepest?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: O no, but dream the most fantastical: oh heaven: oh fubbery, fubbery.

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.p: Dream, what dreamest?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Why methinks I see that signior pawned his foot-cloth, that Metreza her plate, this madam takes physic, that tother monsieur may minister to her: here is a pandar jewelled: there a fellow in shift of satin this day, that could not shift a shirt tother night, here a Paris supports that Helen,
there's a lady Guinever bears up that sir Lancelot. Dreams, dreams, visions, fantasies, chimaeras, imaginations, tricks, conceits,to Prepasso. sir Tristram Trimtram come a loft jackanapes with a whim-wham , here's a knight of the land of Catito shall play at trap with any page in Europe; do the sword dance, with any morris ▪ dancer in Christendom; ride at the ring till the fin of his eyes look as blue as the welkin, and run the wild-goose chase even with Pompey the huge.

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.p: You run.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: To the devil: now signior Guerchino; that thou from a most pitied prisoner shouldst grow a most loathed flatterer: alas poor Celso, thy stars oppressed, thou art an honest lord, 'tis pity.

sp.speaker: Equato.
sp.p: Is't pity?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I marry is't philosophical Equato, and 'tis pity that thou being so excellent a scholar by art, shouldst be so ridiculous a fool by nature: I have a thing to tell you Duke; bid 'em avant, bid 'em avant.

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.p: Leave us, leave us, now sir what is't?

div.stage: Exeunt all saving Pietro and Malevole

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Duke thou art a beco, a cornuto.

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Thou art a cuckold.

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.p: Speak; unshale him quick.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: With most tumbler-like nimbleness.

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.p: Who? by whom? I burst with desire.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Mendozo is the man makes thee a horned beast; Duke 'tis Mendozo cornutes thee.

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.p: What conformance, relate, short, short.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: As a lawyer's beard,

lg.l: There is an old crone in the court, her name is Maquerelle,
She is my mistress sooth to say, and she doth ever tell me,

sp.p: Blirt a rhyme; blirt a rhyme; Maquerelle is a cunning bawd, I am an honest villain, thy wife is a close drab, and thou art a notorious cuckold, farewell Duke.

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.p: Stay ▪ stay.

sp.speaker: Mal,
sp.p: Dull, dull Duke, can lazy patience make lame revenge; oh God for a woman to make a man that which God never created, never made.

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.p: What did God never make?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: A cuckold: to be made a thing that's hoodwinked with kindness whilst every rascal philips his brows; to have a coxcomb with egregious horns pinned to a lord's back, every page sporting himself with delightful laughter, whilst he must be the last must know it; pistols and poniards, pistols and poniards.

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.p: Death and damnation.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Lightning and thunder.

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.p: Vengeance and torture.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Catzo.

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.p: O revenge.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I would dam him and all his generation, my own hands should do it; ha I would not trust heaven with my vengeance any thing.

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.p: Any thing, any thing Malevole thou shalt see instantly what temper my spirit holds; farewell, remember, I forget thee not, farewell.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: My honoured lord.

lg.l: Peace, speak low; peace, oh Celso, constant lord,
Thou to whose faith I only rest discovered,
Thou one of full ten millions of men
That lovest virtue only for itself,
Thou in whose hands old Ops may put her soul;
Behold for ever banished Altofront
This Genoa's last years Duke. O truly noble,
I wanted those old instruments of state,
Dissemblance, and suspect: I could not time it Celso,
my throne stood like a point in midst of a circle,
To all of equal nearness, bore with none:
Reigned all alike, so slept in fearless virtue,
Suspectless, too suspectless, till the crowd:
(Still liquorous of untried novelties)
Impatient with severer government:
Made strong with Florence: banished Altofront.
Strong with Florence, I thence your mischief rose,
For when the daughter of the Florentine:
Was matched once with this Pietro now Duke,
No stratagem of state untried was left, till you of all
Of all was quite bereft,
Alas Maria too close prisoned:
My true faithed Duchess i'the citadel.

sp.speaker: Celso.
sp.p: I'll still adhere, let's mutiny and die.

sp.speaker: Mal.

lg.l: O climb not ▪ a falling tower Celso,
'Tis well held desperation, no zeal:
Hopeless to strive with fate (Peace) temporize.
Hope, hope, that never forsakest the wretchedst man,
Yet bidst me live, and lurk in this disguise,
What play I well the ●ree breathed discontent,

sp.p: Why man we are all philosophical monarchs or natural fools, Celso the courts a ●ar, the Duchess sheets will smoke forth ere it be long: impure Mendozo that sharp nosed lord, that made the cursed match linked Genoa with Florence now broad horns, the Duke which he now knows: discord to malcontents is very manna, when the ranks are burst ▪ then scuffle Altophant.

sp.speaker: Celso.
sp.p: I but durst.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: 'Tis gone, 'tis swallowed like a mineral, some way 'twill work, phewt I'll not shrink,
He's resolute who can no lower sink.

sp.speaker: Celso.
sp.p: Yonder's Mendoza.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: True, the privy key.

sp.speaker: Celso.
sp.p: I take my leave sweet lord.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: 'Tis fit, away.

div.head: Scaena qvinta.
div.stage: Enter Mendoza with three or four suitors.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Leave your suits with me, I can and will: attend my secretary, leave me.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Mendoza hark ye, hark ye, you are a treacherous villain, God buy ye.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Out you base born rascal.

sp.speaker: M●l.
sp.p: We are all the sons of heaven though a tripe wife were our mother; a you whoreson hot rained he marmoset, Aegisthus didst ever here of one Aegisthus?

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Gistus?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I Aegisthus, he was a filthy incontinent fleshmonger, such a one as thou art.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Out grumbling rogue.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Orestes, beware Orestes.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Out beggar.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I once shall rise,

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Thou rise?

lg.l: I at the resurrection.
No vulgar seed but once may rise and shall,
No King so huge, but fore he dies may fall.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p:
Now good Elysium, what a delicious heaven is it for a man to be in a prince's favour? O sweet God, o pleasure! O fortune! O all thou best of life? what should I think? what say? what do? to be a favourite? A minion? to have a general timorous respect ▪ observe a man, a stateful silence in his presence: solitariness in his absence, a confused ham and busy murmur of obsequious suitors training him; the cloth held up, and way proclaimed before him; petitionary vassals licking the pavement with their slavish knees, whilst some odd palace lampreeles that engender with snakes, and are full of eyes on both sides with a kind of insinuating humbleness fix all their lights upon his brow: oh blessed state what a
ravishing prospect doth the Olympus of favour yield; death, I cornute the Duke: sweet women, most sweet ladies, nay angels; by heaven he is more accursed than a devil that hates you, or is hated by you, and happier than a god that loves you, or is beloved by you; you preservers of mankind, life blood of society, who would live, nay who can live without you? O paradise, how majestical is your austerer presence? how imperiously chaste is your more modest face? but o! how full of ravishing attraction is your pretty, petulant, languishing, lasciviously-composed countenance: these amorous smiles, those soul-warming sparkling glances; ardent as those flames that singed the world by heedless Phaeton; in body how delicate, in soul how witty, in discourse how pregnant, in life how wary, in favours how judicious, in day how sociable, and in night how? O pleasure unutterable, indeed it is most certain, one man cannot deserve only to enjoy a beauteous woman: but a Duchess? in despite of Phoebus I'll write a sonnet instantly in praise of her.

div.head: Scaena sexta.
div.stage: Enter Farnese ushering Aurelia, Emillia and Maquerelle bearing up her train, Beancha attending: all go out but Aurelia, Maquerelle and Farneze.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.p: And is't possible? Mendozo slight me, possible?

lg.l: Possible? what can be strange in him that's drunk with favour,
Grows insolent with grace, speak Maquerelle, speak.

sp.speaker: Maque.
sp.p:
To speak feelingly, more, more richly in solid sense then worthless words, give me those jewels of your ears to receive my enforced duty, as for my part 'tis well known I can put up any thing; can bear patiently with any man: but when I heard he wronged your precious sweetness, I was enforced to take deep offence; 'tis most certain he loves Emillia with high appetite; and as she told
me (As you know we women impart our secrets one to another) when she repulsed his suit, in that he was possessed with your endeared grace: Mendozo most ingratefully renounced all faith to you.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Nay, called you, speak Maquerelle, speak.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: By heaven witch? dried biscuit, and contested blushlessly he loved you but for a spurt or so.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: For maintenance.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Advancement and regard.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: O villain? O impudent Mendozo.

sp.speaker: Maq
sp.p: Nay he is the rustiest jawed, the foulest mouthed knave in railing against our sex: he will rail again women.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: How? how?

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: I am ashamed to speak't, I.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I love to hate him, speak.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Why when Emillia scorned his base unsteadiness the black throated rascal scolded, and said.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Troth 'tis too shameless,

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: What said he?

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Why that at four women were fools, at fourteen drabs, at forty bawds, at fourscore witches, and a hundreth cats.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: O unlimitable impudency!

lg.l: But as for poor Ferneze's fixed heart,
Was never shadeless meadow drier parched,
Under the scorching heat of heaven's dog,
Then is my heart with your inforcing eyes.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: A hot simile.

lg.l: Your smiles have been my heaven, your frowns my hell,
Oh pity then; grace should with beauty dwell .

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Reasonable perfect by’r lady.

lg.l: I will love thee, be it but in despite,
Of that Mendozo, witch! Farneze, witch!
Ferneze thou art the Duchess favourite,
Be faithful, private, but 'tis dangerous,
His love is liveless, that for love fears breath,
The worst that's due to sin, oh would't were death.
Enjoy my favour, I will be sick instantly and take physic,
Therefore in depth of night, visit

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Visit her chamber, but conditionally you shall not offend her bed: by this diamond.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: By this diamond.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Nor tarry longer than you please: by this ruby.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: By this ruby.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: And that the door shall not creak.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: And that the door shall not creak.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Nay but swear.

sp.speaker: Ferne.
sp.p: By this purse.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Go to, I'll keep your oaths for you: remember, visit.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Dried biscuit? look where the base wretch comes.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Beauty's life, heaven's model, loves Queen.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: That's his Aemilia.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Nature's triumph, best of earth.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Meaning Emillia.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Thou only wonder that the world hath seen.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: That's Emilia.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Must I then here her praised? Mendozo.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Madam, your excellency is graciously encountered; I have been writing passionate flashes in honour of —

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Out villain, villain, oh judgement where have been my eyes? what bewitched election made me dote on thee? what sorcery made me love thee? but be gone, bury thy head; oh that I could do more than loathe thee: hence worst of ill, no reason else, my reason is my will.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Women? nay furies, nay worse, for they torment only the bad, but women good and bad.

Damnation of mankind, breath hast thou praised them for this: and is't you Ferneze are wriggled into smock grace; fit
sure, oh that I could rail against these monsters in nature, models of hell, curse of the earth, women that dare attempt any thing, and what they attempt they care not how they accomplish, without all premeditation or prevention; rash in asking, desperate in working, impatient in suffering, extreme in desiring, slaves unto appetite, mistresses in dissembling, only constant in unconstancy, only perfect in counterfeiting: their words are feigned, their eyes forged, their sights dissembled, their looks counterfeit, their hair false, their given hopes deceitful, their very breath artificial:
Their blood is their only god: bad clothes, and old age are only the devils they tremble at:
That I could rail now.

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.p: A mischief fill thy throat, thou foul jawed slave▪ say thy prayers.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: I ha' forgotten 'em.

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.p: Thou shalt die.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: So shalt thou; I am heart mad.

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.p: I am horn mad.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Extreme mad.

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.p: Monstrously mad.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.p: Why? thou thou hast dishonoured my bed.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: I? come, come, sit, here's my bare heart to thee as steady as is this centre to this glorious world,
And yet hark thou art a cornuto; but by me?

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.p: Yes slave by thee.

lg.l: Do not, do not with tart and spleenful breath,
Lose him can lose thee; I offend my Duke?
Bare record oh ye dumb and raw aired nights,
How vigilant my sleepless eyes have been,
to watch the traitor; record thou spirit of truth,
With what debasement I ha' throne myself,
To under offices, only to learn
The truth, the party, time, the means, the place,
By whom, and when ▪ and where thou wert disgraced:
And am I paid with slave? hath my intrusion
To places private, and prohibited,
Only to observe the closer passages:
Heaven knows with vows of revelation,
Made me suspected, made me deemed a villain?
What rogue hath wronged us?

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.p: Mendozo, I may err.

lg.l: Err? 'tis too mild a name, but err and err,
Run giddy with suspect, fore through me thou know,
That which most creatures save thyself do know,
Nay since my service hath so loathed reject,
Fore I'll reveal, shalt find them clipped together.

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: Mendozo thou knowest I am a most plain breasted man.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: The fitter to make a cornuto, would your brows were most plane to.

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: Tell me, indeed I heard thee rail?

sp.speaker: Mend.

lg.l: At women, true, why what cold phlegm could choose,
Knowing a lord so honest, virtuous,
So boundless loving, bounteous, fair shaped, sweet,
To be contemned, abused, defamed, made cuckold,

sp.p: Heart, I hate all women for't: sweet sheets, wax lights, antique bedposts, cambric smocks, villainous curtains, arras pictures, oiled hinges, and all ye tongue-tied lascivious witnesses of great creatures wantonness: what salvation can you expect?

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: Wilt thou tell me?

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Why you may find it yourself, observe, observe.

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: I ha' not the patience, wilt thou deserve me; tell, give it.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Take't, why Farneze is the man, Ferneze, I'll prove't, this night you shall take him, in your sheets, wilt serve.

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: It will, my bosom's in some peace, till night.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: Farewell.

lg.l: God how weak a lord are you,
Why do you think there is no more but so?

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: Why?

lg.l: Nay then will I presume to council you,
It should be thus; you with some guard upon the sudden
Break into the prince's chamber, I stay behind
Without the door, through which he needs must pass,
Ferneze flies, let him, to me he comes, he's killed
By me, observe by me, you follow, I rail,
And seem to save the body: Duchess comes
On whom (Respecting her advanced birth,
And your fair nature) I know, nay I do know
No violence must be used. She comes, I storm,
I praise, excuse Ferneze, and still maintain
The Duchess honour, she for this loves me,
I honour you, shall know her soul, you mine,
Then naught shall she contrive in vengeance,
(As women are most thoughtful in revenge)
Of her Ferneze, but you shall sooner know't
Then she can think't, thus shall his death come sure,
Your Duchess brain-caught; so your life secure.
It is too well, my bosom, and my heart,
When nothing helps, cut of the rotten part.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Who cannot feign friendship, can ne'er produce the effects of hatred: honest fool Duke, subtle lascivious Duchess, silly novice Ferneze; I do laugh at ye, my brain is in labour till it produce mischief, and I feel sudden throes, proofs sensible, the issue is at hand.

lg.l: As bear's shape young, so I'll form my device,
Which grown proves horrid: vengeance makes men wise.

div.head: Sce. prima.
div.stage: Enter Mendozo with a scene, to observe Ferneze's entrance, who whilst the act is playing: enter unbraced 2. Pages before him with lights, is met by Maquerelle and conveyed in. The Duchess pages sent away.

lg.l: He's caught, the woodcock's head is i'th noose,
Now treads Ferneze in dangerous path of lust,
Swearing his sense is merely deified.
The fool grasps clouds, and shall beget centaurs.
And now in strength of panting faint delight,
The goat bids heaven envy him; good goose,
I can afford thee nothing but the poor comfort of calamity, pity.
Lusts like the plummets hanging on clock lines,
Will never a done till all is quite is undone.
Such is the course salt sallow lust doth run.
Which thou shalt try; I'll be revenged. Duke thy suspect,
Duchess thy disgrace, Ferneze thy rivalship,
Shall have swift vengeance, nothing so holy,
No band of nature so strong,
No law of friendship so sacred,
But I'll profane, burst, violate
Fore I'll endure disgrace: contempt and poverty:
Shall I whose very hum, struck all heads bare,
Whose face made silence: creaking of whose shoe,
Forced the most private passages fly ope,
Scrape like a servile dog at some latched door?
Learn now to make a leg? and cry beseech ye,
Pray ye is such a lord within? be awed
At some odd ushers scoffed formality?
First sear my brains: unde cadis non quo refert.
My heart cries perish all, how? how? what fate?
Can once avoid revenge, that's desperate,
I'll to the Duke, if all should open, if? tush
Fortune still dotes on those who cannot blush.

div.head: Scaena secunda.
div.stage: Enter Malevole at one door, Beancha, Emillia and Maquerelle at the other door.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Bless ye cast a ladies; ha Dipsas, how dost thou old coal.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Old coal?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I old coal, methinks thou liest like a brand under these billets of green wood.

He that will inflame a young wench's heart, let him lay close to her, an old coal that hath first been fired a panderess, my half burned lint, who though thou canst not flame thyself yet art able to set a 1000. virgins tapers a fire: and how does january thy husband, my little periwinkle: is a troubled with the cough a the lungs still, does he hawk a-nights still, he will not bite.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: No by my troth, I took him with his mouth empty of old teeth.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: And hen took thee with thy belly full of young bones, marry he took his maim by the stroke of his enemy.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: And I mine by the stroke of my friend:

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: The close stock, o mortal wench: lady ha' ye now no restoratives for your decayed Jason, look ye, crabs guts baked, distilled ox-pith, the pulverised hairs of a lion's upper lip, jelly of cock-sparrows, he monkey's marrow, or powder of foxe-stones; and whither are all you ambling now?

sp.speaker: Beanc.
sp.p: Why to bed, to bed.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Do your husband's lie with ye?

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: That were country fashion i'faith.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Ha ye no foregoers about you; come, whither in good deed la now?

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: In good indeed law now, to eat the most miraculously, admirably, astonishable composed posset with three curds, without any drink: will ye help me with a he fox: here's the Duke.

div.head: Scaena Tertia.
div.stage: Enter Duke Pietro, count Celso, count Equato, Bilioso, Ferrard, and Mendozo.

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: The night grows deep and foul, what hour is't?

sp.speaker: Celso.
sp.p: Upon the stroke of twelve.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Save ye Duke.

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: From thee, begone I do not love thee, let me see thee no more, we are displeased.

lg.l: Why God buy thee, heaven hear my curse,
May thy wife and thee live long together.

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: Be gone sirrah.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: When Arthur first in court began, — Agamemnon, Menelaus, — was ever any Duke a cornuto,

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: Begun hence.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: What religion wilt thou be of next?

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Out with him.

lg.l: With most servile patience, time will come,
When wonder of thy error will strike dumb,
Thy befeld sense, slaves I favour, I marry shall he rise,
Good God how subtle hell doth flatter vice,
Mount him aloft, and makes him seem to fly,
As foul the tortoise mocked: who to the sky,
Th'ambitious shell fish raised, th'end of all,
Is only that from height he might dead fall.

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: It shall be so.

lg.l: It must be so, for where great state's revenge,
'Tis requisite, the parts with piety
And soft respect forbears, be closely dogged,
Lay one into his breast shall sleep with him,
Feed in the same dish, run in self faction,
Who may dissever any shape of danger,
For once disgraced, discovered in offence,
It makes man blushless, and man is (All confess)
more prone to vengeance then to gratefulness.
Favours are writ in dust, but stripes we feel,
Depraved nature stamps in lasting steel.

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: You shall be leagued with the Duchess.

sp.speaker: Equat.
sp.p: The plot is very good.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: You shall both kill, and seem the course to save.

sp.speaker: Ferrard.
sp.p: A most fine brain trick.

sp.speaker: Celso.
sp.p: Of a most cunning knave.

lg.l: My lords: the heavy action we intend
Is death and shame, two of the ugliest shapes
That can confound a soul, think, think of it;
I strike but yet like him that 'gainst stone walls,
Directs his shafts, rebounds in his own face,
My lady's shame is mine, oh God, 'tis mine.
Therefore I do conjure all secrecy,
Let it be as very little as may be; pray ye, as may be;
Make frightless entrance, salute her with soft eyes,
Stain naught with blood, only Ferneze dies,
But not before her brows: oh gentlemen
God knows I love her, nothing else, but this
I am not well; if grief that sucks veins dry,
Rivels the skin, casts ashes in men's faces,
Bedulls the eye, unstrengthens all the blood,
Chance to remove me to another world,
As sure I once must die: let him succeed:
I have no child, all that my youth begotten,
Hath been your loves, which shall inherit me,
Which as it ever shall, I do conjure it
Mendozo may succeed, he's nobly born;
With me of much desert.

sp.speaker: Celso.
sp.p: Much.

lg.l: Your silence answers I,
I thank you, come on now, o that I might die,
Before her shames displayed, would I were forced
To burn my father's tomb; unhill his bones,
And dash them in the dirt, rather than this:
this both the living and the dead offends,
Sharp surgery where naught but death amends.

div.head: Scaena qvarta.
div.stage: Enter Maquerelle, Emillia and Beanca, with a posser.

lg.l: Even here it is, three curds in three regions individually distinct,
Most methodically according to art composed, without any drink.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: Without any drink.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Upon my honour, will ye sit and eat.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Good the composure the receive, how is't:

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: 'Tis a pretty pearl, by this pearl, (How dost with me) thus it is, seven and thirty yolks of Barbary hens eggs, eighteen spoonfuls and a half of the joice of cock-sparrow bon s, one ounce, three drams, four scruples, and one quarter of the syrup of Ethiopian dates, sweetened with three quarters of a pound of pure candid Indian 〈◊〉, strowed over with the powder of pearl of America, amber of Cataia, and lamb stones of 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: Trust me the ingredients are very cordial, and no question good, and most powerful in operation.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: I know not what you mean by restauration, but this it doth, it purifieth the blood, smootheth the skin, enliveneth the eye, strengtheneth the veins ▪ mundifieth the teeth, comforteth the stomach, fortifieth the back, and quickeneth the wit, that's all.

sp.speaker: Emil
sp.p: By my troth I have eaten but two spoonfuls, and methinks I could discourse most swiftly, and wittily already.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Have you the art to seem honest.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: I thank advice and practise.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Why then eat me a this posset, quicken your blood, and preserve your beauty, do you know doctor Plaster-face, by this curd he is the most exquisite in forging of veins, sprightning of eyes, dying of hair, sleeking of skins, blushing of cheeks, surpheling of breasts, blanching and bleaching of teeth, that ever made an old lady gracious by torchlight: by this curd law.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: Well we are resolved, what God has given us we'll cherish.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Cherish any thing saving your husband, keep him not too high lest he leap the pale: but for your beauty, let it be your saint, bequeath two hours to it every morning in your closet, I ha' been young, and yet in my conscience I am not above five and twenty, but believe me, preserve and use your beauty, for youth and beauty once gone, we are like beehives without honey: out a fashion, apparel that no man will wear, therefore use me your beauty.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: I but men say.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Men say, let men say what the will, life a woman, they are ignorant of our wants, the more in years the more in perfection the grow: if they lose youth and beauty, they gain wisdom and discretion: but when our beauty fades, goodnight with us, there cannot be an uglier thing to see then an old woman, from which, o pruning, pinching, and painting, deliver all sweet beauties.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: Hark music.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Peace 'tis i'the Duchess bedchamber, good rest most prosperously graced ladies.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: God night centinel.

sp.speaker: Bean,
sp.p: Night dear Maquerelle.

lg.l: May my possets operation send you my wit and honesty,
And me your youth and beauty, the pleasingst rest.

div.head: Scaena qvinta.
div.stage: Whilst the song is singing, enter Mendozo with his sword drawn standing ready to murder Ferneze as he flies from the Duchess chamber.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Strike, strike. tumult within.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Save my Ferneze, o save my Ferneze.

div.stage: Enter Ferneze in his shirt, and is received upon Mendoz. sword.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Follow, pershew.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: O save Ferneze.

lg.l: Pierce, pierce, thou shallow fool drop there,
He that attempts a prince's lawless love,
Must have broad hands, close heart with Argos eyes,
And back of Hercules, or else he dies.

div.stage: Enter Aurelia, Duke Pietro, Ferrard, Bilioso, Celso and Equato.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Follow, follow,

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Stand off, forbear, ye most uncivil lords. Mendozo bestrids the wounded body of Ferneze and seems to save him.

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: Strike.

lg.l: Do not; tempt not a man resolved;
Would you inhumane murderers more than death?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: O poor Ferneze.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Alas now all defence too late.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: He's dead.

lg.l: I am sorry for our shame, go to your bed,
Weep not too much, but leave some tears to shed
When I am dead?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: What weep for thee? my soul no tears shall find.

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: Alas, alas, that women's souls are blind.

lg.l: Betray such beauty? murder such youth? contemn civility,
He loves him not that rails not at him.
Thou canst not move us, we have blood enough;
And please you lady we have quite forgotten
all your defects: if not, why then

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Not.

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: Not: the best of rest, good night.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Despite go with thee.

lg.l: Madam, you ha' done me soul disgrace,
You have wronged him much, loves you too much.
Go to; your soul knows you have.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I think I have.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Do you but think so?

lg.l: Nay sure I have, my eyes have witnessed thy love,
Thou hast stood too firm for me.
Why tell me fair checked lady, who even in tears
Art powerfully beauteous, what unadvised passion
Struck ye into such a violent heat against me,
Speak, what mischief wronged us? what devil injured us?
Speak?
That thing never worthy of the name of man; Ferneze,
Ferneze swore thou lovest Emillia,
Which to advance, with most reproachful breath,
Thou both didst blemish and denounce my love.
Ignoble villain, did I for this bestride
Thy wounded limbs; for this? rank opposite
Even to my sovereign: for this? O God for this?
Sunk all my hopes, and with my hopes my life,
Ripped bare my throat unto the hangman's axe,
Thou most dishonoured trunk — Emillia?
By life I know her not — Emillia?
Did you believe him?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Pardon me, I did.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Did you, and thereupon you graced him?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I did.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Took him to favour, nay even clasped with him?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Alas I did.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: This night?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: This night.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: And in your lustful twines the Duke took you?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: A most sad truth.

lg.l: O God, oh God, how we dull honest souls,
Heavy brained men, are swallowed in the bogs
Of a deceitful ground, whilst nimble bloods,
Light jointed spirits pent, cut good men's throats,
And scape alas, I am too honest for this age,
Too full of phlegm ▪ and heavy steadiness:
Stood still whilst this slave cast a noose about me;
Nay than to stand in honour of him, and her,
Who had even sliced my heart.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Come I did err, and am most sorry, I did err.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Why we are both but dead, the Duke hates us,

lg.l: „ and those whom princes do once groundly hate,
„ let them provide to die; as sure as fate,
„ prevention is the heart of policy.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Shall we murder him.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Instantly?

lg.l: Instantly, before he casts a plot,
Or further blaze my honours much known blot,
Let's murder him?

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: I would do much for you, will ye marry me?

lg.l: I'll make thee Duke, we are of Medici's,
Florence our friend, in court my faction
Not meanly strength ▪ full; the Duke then dead,
We well prepared for change, the multitude
Irresolutely reeling, we in force,
Our party seconded, the kingdom mazde,
No doubt of swift success all shall be graced.
You do confirm me, we are resolute,
Tomorrow look for change, rest confident,
'Tis now about the immodest waste of night,
The mother of moist dew with pallid light,
Spreads gloomy shades about the numbed earth,
Sleep, sleep, whilst we contrive our mischief's birth,
This man I'll get inhumed, farewell, to bed,
I kiss thy pillow ▪ dream, the Duke is dead. Exit Aurelia.
So, so, good night, how fortune dotes on impudence,
I am in private the adopted son of yond good prince,
I must be Duke, why if I must, I must,
Most silly lord, name me? O heaven
I see God made honest fools, to maintain crafty knaves:
The Duchess is wholly mine too; must kill her husband
To quit her shame, much: then marry her: ay,
O ● grow proud in prosperous treachery,
As wrestlers clip, so I'll embrace you all,
Not to support, but to procure your fall.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: God arrest thee.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: At whose suit?

lg.l: At the devils, ha' you treacherous damnable monster,
How dost ▪ how dost thou treacherous rogue,
Ha ye rascal, I am banish the court, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Prithee let's be acquainted, I do love thee faith.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: At your service, by the lord law, shall's go to supper, let's be once drunk together ▪ and so unite a most virtuously strengthened friendship, shall's Huguenot, shall's?

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Wilt ●ll upon my chamber tomorrow morn.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: As a raven to a dunghill, they say there's one dead here pricked for the pride of the flesh.

sp.speaker: Mend
sp.p: Fernez: there he is, pray thee bury him.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Oh most willingly, I mean to turn pure Rochelle churchman, I.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Thou churchman, why? why?

sp.speaker: Mal
sp.p: Because I'll live lazily, fail upon authority, deny King's supremacy in things indifferent, and be a Pope in mine own parish.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Wherefore dost thou think churches were made?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: To scour plough shares 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 plough up altars:

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Strange.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Nay monstrous, I ha' seen a sumptuous steeple turned to a stinking privy: more beastly, the sacredst place made a dog's kennel: nay most inhumane, the stoned coffins of long dead Christians burst up, and made hogs-troughs.
Shall I ha' some sack, and cheese at thy chamber, good night, good mischivous incarnate devil, goodnight Mendozo, ha, ye inhuman villain goodnight, night fub:

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: God night: tomorrow morn.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Ay, I will come friendly damnation, I will come, I do descry cross-points, honesty, and courtship, straddle as far asunder, as a true Frenchman's legs.

sp.speaker: Ferne.
sp.p: O!

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Proclamations, more proclamations.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: O a surgeon.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Hark lust cries for a surgeon, what news from limb how does the grand cuckold Lucifer.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: O help, help, conceal and save me.

div.stage: Ferneze stirs and male. helps him up and conveys him away.

lg.l: Thy shame more than thy wounds do grieve me far,
„ thy wounds but leave upon thy flesh some scar:
„ but fame ne'er heals still rankles worse and worse,
„ such is of uncontrolled lust the curse.
„ think what it is in lawless sheets to lie,
„ but o Ferneze what in lust to die:
„ then thou that shame respects o fly converse,
„ with women's eyes and lisping wantonness:
„ stick candles 'gainst a virgin walls white back,
„ if they not burn, yet at the least they'll black,
Come I'll convey thee to a private port,
Where thou shalt live (Oh happy man) from court.
The beauty of the day begins to rise,
From whose bright form night's heavy shadow flies.
Now begins 〈◊〉 plots to work, the scene grows full,
And craves 〈◊〉 eyes who hath a solid skull.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Pietro the Duke, mendoz: count Equato and Bilioso.

lg.l: 'Tis grown to youth of day, how shall we waste this light?
My heart's more heavy than a tyrant's crown.
Shall we go hunt? Prepare for field.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Would ye could be merry.

lg.l: Would God I could: Mendoza bid am haste. Exit Mendo.
I would fain shift place, oh vain relief.
„ sad souls may well change place, but not change grief:
As deer being struck fly thorough many soils,
Yet still the shaft stick fast, so, a good old simile my honest lord,
I am not much unlike to some sick-man,
That long desired hurtful drink; at last
Swills in and drinks his last, ending at once
Both life and thirst: oh would I ne'er had known
My own dishonour: good God, that men should
Desire to search out that, which being found kills all
Their joy of life: to taste the tree of knowledge,
And then be driven from out paradise.
Canst give me some comfort?

sp.speaker: Bili.
sp.p: My lord, I have some books which have been dedicated to my honour, and I near read am, and yet they had very fine names: physic for fortune: lozinges of sanctified sincerity; very pretty works of curates, scriveners and schoolmasters. Marry I remember one Seneca, Lucius Aneus Seneca.

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: Out upon him, he writ of temperance and fortitude, yet lived like a voluptuous epicure, and died like an effeminate coward. Hast thee to Florence: here take our letters, see 'em sealed, away: report in private to the honoured Duke his daughter's forced disgrace, tell him at length we know too much, due complaints advance.
There's naught that's safe and sweet but ignorance.

div.head: Scaena secunda.
div.stage: Enter Malevole in some freeze gown whilst Bilioso reads his patent.

lg.l: I cannot sleep my eyes ill neighbouring lids
Will hold no fellowship: oh thou pale sober night,
Thou that in sluggish fumes all sense dost steep:
Thou that gives all the world full leave to play,
Unbendest the feebled veins of sweaty labour;
The galleyslave, that all the toilsome day,
Tugs at his oar against the stubborn wave,
Straining his rugged veins; snores fast:
The stooping S●heman that doth barb the field,
Thou ▪ mak'st wink sure: in night all creatures sleep,
Only the malcontent, that 'gainst his fate,
Repines and quarrels, alas he's goodman Tell-clock,
His sallow jaw-bones sink with wasting moan,
Whilst other beds are down, his pillows stone.

sp.speaker: Bili.
sp.p: Mal vole.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Elder of Israel, thou honest defect of wicked nature and obstinate ignorance, when did thy wife let thee lie with her?

sp.speaker: Bili.
sp.p: I am going ambassador to Florence.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Ambassador, now for thy country's honour, prithee do not put up mutton and porridge i'thy clock bag: thy young lady wife goes to Florence with thee too does she not?

sp.speaker: Bili.
sp.p: No, I leave her at the palace.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: At the palace? now discretion shield man, for god's love let's ha' no more cuckolds, Hymen begins to put of his saffron robe, keep thy wife i'the state of grace, heart a truth, I would sooner leave my lady singled in a bordello, then in the Genoa palace, sin there appearing in her sluttish shape would soon grow loath some, even to blushes sense,

lg.l: Surfeit would cloak intemperate appetite,
Make the soul scent the rotten breath of lust.
When in an Italian lascivious palace, a lady guardianless.
Left to the push of all allurement,
The strongest incitements to immodesty,
to have her bound, incensed with wanton sweets,
Her veins filled high with heating delicates,

sp.p: Soft rest, sweet music, amorous masquerers, lascivious banquets, sin itself gilt o'er, strong fantasy tricking up strange delights, presenting it dressed pleasingly to sense, sense leading it unto the soul, confirmed with potent example, impudent custom enticed by that great bawd opportunity, thus being prepared, clap to her easy ear, youth in good clothes, well shaped, rich, fair spoken, promising noble, ardent blood-full, witty, flattering, Ulysses absent, oh Ithaca can chastest Penelope hold out.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Mass I'll think on't farewell.

lg.l: Farewell, take thy wife with thee, farewell,
To Florence, umh? it may prove good, it may,
And we may once unmask our brows.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: My honoured lord.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Celso peace, how is't? speak lo, pale fears suspect that hedges, walls and trees have ears, speak how runs all?

lg.l: I'faith my lord, that beast with many heads,
The staggering multitude recoils apace,
Though thorough great men's envy, most men's malice,
Their much intemperate heat hath banished you.
Yet now they feigned envy and malice near,
Produce faint reformation.
The Duke, the too soft Duke lies as a block,
For which two tugging factions seem to saw,
But still the iron through the ribs they draw.
I tell thee Celzo, I have ever found
Thy breast most far from shifting cowardice
And fearful baseness: therefore I'll tell thee Celzo,
I find the wind begins to come about,
I'll shift my suit of fortune, I know the Florentine whose only force,
By marrying his proud daughter to this prince,
Both banished me, and made this weak lord Duke,
Will now forsake them all, be sure he will:
I'll lie in ambush for conveniency,
Upon their severance to confirm myself.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Is Ferneze interred?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Of that at leisure: he lives.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: But how stands Mendoza, how is't with him?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Faith like a pair of snuffers, snibs filth in other men, and retains it in himself.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: He does fly from public notice methinks , as a hair does from hounds, the feet whereon he flies betrays him.

lg.l: I can track him Celzo:
Oh my disguise fools him most powerfully:
For that I seem a desperate malcontent
He fain would clasp with me: he is the true slave,
That will put on the most affected grace,Enter Mendoz.
For some vild second cause.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: He's here.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Give place.
Illo, ho ho ho, art there old true penny,
Where hast thou spent thyself this morning? I see flattery in thine eyes, and damnation i'thy soul. Ha ye huge rascal.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Thou art very merry.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: As a scholar futuens gratis: how does the devil go with thee now.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Malevole, thou art an arrant knave.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Who I? I have been a sergeant man.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Thou art very poor.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: As Job, an alchemist, or a poet.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: The Duke hates thee.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: As Irishmen do bum-cracks.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Thou hast lost his amity.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: As pleasing as maids lose their virginity.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Would thou wert of a lusty spirit, would thou wert noble.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Why sure my blood gives me I am noble, sure I am of noble kind, for I find myself possessed with all their qualities: love dogs, dice and drabs ▪ scorn wit in stuff clothes, have beaten my shoemaker, knocked my sempstress, cuckold my pothecary, and undone my tailor.

Noble, why not? since the Stoic said; neminem seruum non
ex regibus, neminem regem non ex servis esse oriundum, only busy fortune towses, and the provident chances blends them together; I'll give you a simile: did you ere see a well with 2. buckets, whilst one comes up full to be emptied, another goes down empty to be filled; such is the state of all humanity: why look you, I may be the son of some Duke, for believe me intemperate lascivious bastardy makes nobility doubtful, I have a lusty daring heart Mendoza.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Let's grasp? I do like thee infinitely, wilt enact one thing for me?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Shall I get by it?
Command me, I am thy slave, beyond death and hell.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Murder the Duke?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: My heart's wish, my soul's desire, my fantasies dream, my blood's longing, the only height of my hopes, how? O God how? O how my united spirits throng together, so strengthen my resolve.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: The Duke is now a hunting.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Excellent, admirable, as the devil would have it, lend me, lend me, rapier Pistol, crossbow: so, so, I'll do it.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Then we agree.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: As Lent and fishmongers, come a cape ape, how in form?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Know that this weak brained Duke, who only stands on Florence stilts, hath out of witless zeal made me his heir, and secretly confirmed the wreath to me after his life's full point.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Upon what merit?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Merit? by heaven I horn him, only Ferneze's death gave me state's life: tut we are politic, he must not live now.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: No reason marry: but how must he die now.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: My utmost project is to murder the Duke, that I might have his state, because he makes me his heir: to banish the Duchess, that I might be rid of a cunning Lacedaemonian, because I know Florence will forsake her, and then to marry Maria the banished Duke Altofront's wife, that her friends might strengthen me and my faction, this is all law.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Do you love Maria.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: Faith no great affection, but as wise men do love great women to ennoble their blood and augment their revenue: to accomplish this now, thus now. The Duke is in the forest next the sea, single him ▪ kill him, hurl him i'the main, and proclaim thou sawest wolves eat him.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Umh, not so good, methinks when he is slain to get some hypocrite, some dangerous wretch that's muffled, or with feigned holiness to swear he hard the Duke on some steep cliff lament his wife's dishonour, and in an agony of his heart's torture hurled his groaning sides into the swollen sea, this circumstance well made, sounds probable, and hereupon the Duchess.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: May well be banished: o unpeerable invention, rare, thou god of policy! it hunnies me.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Then fear not for the wife of Altofront, I'll close to her.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Thou shalt, thou shalt, our excellency is pleased: why wert not thou an emperor, when we are Duke I'll make thee some great man sure?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Nay make me some rich knave, and I'll make myself some great man.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p: In thee be all my spirit, retain ten souls, unite thy virtual powers, resolve, ha, remember greatness, heart farewell.
The fate of all my hopes in thee doth dwell.

lg.l: Celzo didst hear? O heaven didst hear?
Such devilish mischief, sufferest thou the world
Carouse damnation even with greedy swallow,
And still dost wink, still does thy vengeance slumber,
If now thy brows are clear; when will they thunder.

div.head: Scaena qvarta.
div.stage: Enter Pietro, Ferrard, Prespasso and three pages.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.p: The dogs are at a fault.

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p:
Would God nothing but the dogs were at it? let the deer pursue safely, the dogs follow the game, and do
you follow the dogs, as for me, 'tis unfit one beast should hunt another; I ha' one chaseth me: and please you I would be rid of ye a little.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.p: Would your grief would as soon as we, leave you to quietness.

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: I thank you: boy; what dost thou dream of now?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Of a dry summer my lord for here's a h●e world towards: but my lord I had a strange dream last night.

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: What strange dream?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Why methought I pleased you with singing, and then I dreamt you gave me that short sword.

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: Prettily begged: hold thee, I'll prove thy dream true, take't.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: My duty: but still I dreamt on my lord, and methought and shall please your excellency, you would needs out of your royal bounty give me that jewel in your hat.

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: O thou didst but dream boy, do not believe it, dreams prove not always true, they may hold in a short sword, but not in a jewel. But now sir you dream you had pleased me with singing, make that true as I ha' made the other.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Faith my lord I did but dream, and dreams you say prove not always true: they may hold in a good sword, but not in a good song: the truth is, I ha' lost my voice.

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: Lost thy voice, how?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: With dreaming faith but here's a couple of sirenical rascals shall inchant ye: what shall they sing my good lord?

sp.speaker: Piet ▪
sp.p: Sing of the nature of women, and then the song shall be surely full of variety, old crochets and most sweet closes; it shall be humorous, grave, fantastic, amorous, melancholy, sprightly, one in all, and all in one.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: All in on?

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: By'r lady too many sing, my speech grows culpable of unthrifty idleness, sing.

div.head: Scaena qvinta.
div.stage: Enter Malevole with crosebowe and pistol.
div.p: A, so. so, sing, I am heavy, walk of, I shall talk in my sleep walk of.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Brief, brief, who? the Duke? good heaven that fools should stumble upon greatness? do not sleep Duke, give ye good morrow: must be brief Duke. I am feed to murder thee, start not; Mendozo, Mendozo hired me, here's his gold, his pistol, crossbow, sword, 'tis all as firm as earth: oh fool, fool, choked with the common maze of easy idiots, credulity make him thine heir, what thy sworn murderer?

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.p: O can it be?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Can?

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.p: Discovered he not Ferneze?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Yes, but why? but why? for love to thee, much, much, to be revenged upon his rival, who had thrust his jaws awry, who being slain supposed by thine own hands; defended by his sword, made thee most loathsome, him most gracious, with thy loose princes, thou closely yielding egress and regress to her, madest him heir, whose hot unquiet lust straight towzed thy sheets, and now would seize thy state, politician, wise man, death to be led to the stake, like a bull by the horns to make even kindness cut a gentle throat, life, why art thou numbed: thou foggy dulness speak? lives not more faith in a home thrusting tongue, then in these fencing tip tap courtiers.

div.stage: Enter Celso with a hermit's gown and beard.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Lord Malevole, if this be true

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: If? come shade thee with this disguise, if? thou shalt handle it, he shall thank thee for killing thyself, come follow my directions, and thou shalt see strange sleights.

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.p: World whether wilt thou?

lg.l: Why to the devil: come, the morn grows late.
A steady quickness is the soul of state.

div.head: Scen. prima.
div.stage: Enter Maquarelle, knocking at the lady's door.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Medam, Medam, are you stirring madam, if you be stirring Medam, if I thought I should disturb ye.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: My lady is up forsooth.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: A, pretty boy, faith how old art thou?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: I think fourteen.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Nay, and ye be in the teens, are ye a gentleman born, do you know me, my name is Medam Maquerelle, I lie in the old coney court.
See here the ladies.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: A fair day to ye Maquerelle.

sp.speaker: Emili.
sp.p: Is the Duchess up yet sentinel?

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: O ladies, the most abominable mischance, oh dear ladies the most piteous disaster, Farneze was taken last night in the Duchess chamber: alas the Duke catched him and killed him.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: Was he found in bed?

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: O no, but the villainous certainty is, the door was not bolted, the tongue-tied hatch held his peace, so the naked troth is, he was found in his shirt, whilst I like an errand beast lay in the outward chamber, heard nothing, and yet they came by me in the dark, and yet I felt them not, like a senseless creature as I was. O beauties, look to your busk-points, if not chastely, yet charily: be sure the door be bolted: is your lord gone to Florence?

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: Yes Maquarelle.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p:
I hope you'll find the discretion to purchase a fresh gown fore his return: now by my troth beauties,
I would ha' ye once wise: he loves ye, pish: he is witty, bubble: fair proportioned, mew: nobly born, wind; let this be still your fixed position, esteem me every man according to his good gifts, and so ye shall ever remain most dear, and most worthy to be most dear ladies.

sp.speaker: Emilia.
sp.p: Is the Duke returned from hunting yet?

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: They say, not yet.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: 'Tis now in midst of day.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: How bears the Duchess with this blemish now?

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Faith boldly, strongly defies defame, as one that has a Duke to her father. And there's a note to you, be sure of a stout friend in a corner, that may always awe your husband. Mark the behaviour of the Duchess now, she dares defame, cries, Duke do what thou canst, I'll quite mine honour: nay, as one confirmed in her own virtue against ten thousand mouths that mutter her disgrace, she's presently for dances.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: For dances?

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Most true.

sp.speaker: Enusia.
sp.p: Most strange, see, here's my servant young Ferrard: how many servants thinkst thou I have, Maquarelle?

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: The more the merrier: 'twas well said, use your servants as you do your smocks, have many, use one, and change often, for that's most sweet and courtlike.

sp.speaker: Ferrar.
sp.p: Save ye fair ladies, is the Duke returned?

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: Sweet sir, no voice of him as yet in court.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: 'Tis very strange.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: And how like you my servant, Maquarelle?

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: I think he could hardly draw Ulysses bow, but by my fidelity, were his nose narrower, his eyes broader, his hands thinner, his lips thicker, his legs bigger, his feet lesser, his hair blacker, and his teeth whiter, he were a tolerable sweet youth i'faith. And he will come to my chamber, I will read him the fortune of his beard.

lg.l: Not yet returned I fear, but
The Duchess approacheth.

div.stage: Enter Mendozo supporting the Duchess: Guerrino, the ladies that are on the stage rise: Ferrard ushers in the Duchess, and then takes a lady to tread a measure.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: We will dance, music, we will dance.

sp.speaker: Guer.
sp.p: Lesquanto (Lady) penses bien, passa regis, or Bianca's brawl.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: We have forgotten the brawl.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: So soon? 'tis wonder.

sp.speaker: Guerrino
sp.p: Why 'tis but two singles on the left, two on the right, three double forward, a traverse of six round: do this twice, three singles side, galliard trick of twenty, coranto pace; a figure of eight, three singles broken down, come up, meet two doubles, fall back, and then honour.

sp.speaker: Aurelia
sp.p: O Dedalus! thy maze, I have quite forgotten it.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Trust me so have I, saving the falling back, and then honour.

sp.speaker: Aurelia
sp.p: Music, music.

sp.speaker: Prepasso
sp.p: Who saw the Duke? the Duke.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.p: Music.

sp.speaker: Equato
sp.p: The Duke, is the Duke returned?

sp.speaker: Aurelia
sp.p: Music:

sp.speaker: Celso
sp.p: The Duke is either quite invisible, or else is not.

sp.speaker: Aurelia
sp.p: We are not pleased with your intrusion upon our private retirement: we are not pleased: you have forgotten yourselves.

sp.speaker: Celso
sp.p: Boy, thy master, where's the Duke?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p:
Alas, I left him burying the earth with his spread joyless limbs: he told me he was heavy, would sleep, bade
me walk off, for that the strength of fantasy oft made him talking in his dreams: I straight obeyed, nor never saw him since: but, wheresoe'er he is, he's sad.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Music sound high, as is our heart, sound high.

div.head: Scaena Tertia.
div.stage: Enter Malevole and Pietro disguised like an hermit.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: The Duke, peace, the Duke is dead.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.p: Music.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Is't music?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Give proof.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Where.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Rest in peace, as the Duke does, quietly sit: for my own part, I beheld him but dead, that's all: marry here's one can give you a more particular account of him.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Speak holy father, nor let any brow within this presence fright thee from the truth: speak confidently and freely.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: We attend.

lg.l: Now had the mounting suns all-ripening wings
Swept the cold sweat of night from earth's dank breast,
When I (Whom men call hermit of the rock)
Forsook my cell, and clambered up a cliff,
Against whose base, the heady Neptune dashed
His high curled brows, there was I eased my limbs,
When lo, my entrails melted with the moan,
Some one, who far 'bove me was climbed, did make:
I shall offend.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Not.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: On.

lg.l: Methinks I hear him yet, oh female faith!
Go sow the ingrateful sand, and love a woman:
And do I live to be the scoff of men,
To be their wittal cuckold, even to hug my poison?
Thou knowest o truth!
Sooner hard steel will melt with Southern wind;
A seaman's whistle calm the ocean;
A town on fire be extinct with tears,
Than women vowed to blushless impudence,
With sweet behaviour and soft minioning,
Will turn from that where appetite is fixed.
O powerful blood! how thou dost slave their soul?
I washed an Aethiop, who for recompense
Sullied my name. And must I then be forced.
To walk, to live thus black: must, must, fie,
He that can bear with must, he cannot die.
With that he sighed so passionately deep,
That the dull air even groaned, at last he cries:
Sink shame in seas, sink deep enough, so dies.
For then I viewed his body fall and souse
Into the foamy main, oh then I saw
That which methinks I see, it was the Duke,
Whom straight the nicer stomached sea
Belched up: but then,
Then came I in, but 'las all was too late,
For even straight he sunk.

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.p: Such was the Duke's sad fate.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: A better fortune to our Duke Mendozo.
Cry all, Mendozo: cornets flourish.

lg.l: A guard, a guard, we full of hearty tears,
For our good father's loss,
For so we well may call him:
Who did beseech your loves, for our succession,
Cannot so lightly over-jump his death.
As leave his woes revengeless:to Emilia, woman of shame,
We banish thee for ever to the place,
From whence this good man comes,
Nor permit on death unto the body any ornament:
But base as was thy life, depart away.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Ungrateful.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Away.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Villain hear me.

div.stage: Prepasso and Guerino leads away the Duchess.

lg.l: Be gone my lords, address to public counsel,
'Tis most fit,
The train of fortune is born up by wit.
Away, our presence shall be sudden, haste.

div.stage: All depart saving Mendozo, Malevole, and Pietro.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Now you egregious devil, ha ye murdering politician, how dost Duke? how dost look now? brave Duke i'faith.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.p: How did you kill him?

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Slatted his brains out, then soused him in the briny sea.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.p: Brained him and drowned him too?

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: O 'twas best, sure work:
For he that strikes a great man, let him strike home, or else beware, he'll prove no man: shoulder not a huge fellow, unless you may be sure to lay him in the kennel.

lg.l: A most sound brain pan,
I'll make you both emperors

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Make us Christians, make us Christians.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.p: I'll hoist ye, ye shall mount.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: To the gallows, say ye? O o me, pranium incertum petit certum scelus. How stands the progress?

lg.l: Here, take my ring unto the citadel,
Have entrance to Maria the grave Duchess
Of banished Altofront. Tell her we love her:
Omit no circumstance to grace our person (Do't)

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Iste make an excellent pandar: Duke farewell, due adieu Duke.

lg.l: Take Maquerelle with thee; for 'tis found,
None cuts a diamond but a diamond.
Hermit, thou art a man for me, my confessor,
Oh thou selected spirit, born for my good,

Sure thou wouldst make an excellent elder in a deformed
church:
Come, we must be inward, thou and I all one.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.p: I am glad I was ordained for ye.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Go to then, thou must know that Malevole is a strange villain: dangerous, very dangerous, you see how broad 'a speaks, a gross-jawed rogue, I would have thee poison him: he's like a corn upon my great toe, I cannot go for him: he must be kored out: he must, wilt do't, hu?

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.p: Anything, any thing.

lg.l: Heart of my life, thus then to the citadel,
Thou shalt consort with this Malevole,
There being at supper, poison him,
It shall be laid upon Maria, who yields love, or dies,
Skud quick.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.p: Like lightning good deeds crawl, but mischief flies.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Your divelships ring haze no virtue, the buff-captain, the Sallo-westfalian gamon-faced zaza cries stand out, must have a stiffer warrant, or no pass into the castle of comfort.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Command our sudden letter: not enter? sha●, what place is there in Genoa, but thou shalt into my heart, into my very heart: come, let's love, we must love, we two, soul and body.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: How didst like the hermit? A strange hermit sirrah.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: A dangerous fellow, very perilous: he must die.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Ay, he must die.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Thoust kill him: we are wise, we must be wise.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: And provident.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Yea provident; beware an hypocrite.

lg.l: A church man once corrupted, o avoid ▪
A fellow that makes religion his stawking horse,
He breeds a plague: thou shalt poison him.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Ho, 'tis wondrous necessary: how?

lg.l: You both go jointly to the citadel,
There sup, there poison him: and Maria,
Because she is our opposite, shall bear
The sad suspect, on which she dies, or loves us.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: I run.

lg.l: We that are great, our sole self good still moves us:
They shall die both, for their deserts craves more
Than we can recompense, their presence still
Imbraids our fortunes with beholdingness,
Which we abhor, like deed, not door: then conclude,
They live not to cry out ingratitude.
One stick burns tother, steel cuts steel alone:
'Tis good trust few: but oh, 'tis best trust none.

div.head: Scaena qvarta.
div.stage: Enter Malevole and Pietro still disguised, at several doors.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: How do you? how dost Duke?

lg.l: O let the last day fall, drop, drop in our cursed heads!
Let heaven unclasp itself, vomit forth flames:

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: O do not rave, do not turn player, there's more of them, than can well live one by another already. What, art an infidel still?

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.p: I am amazed, struck in a swoon with wonder, I am commanded to poison thee.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: I am commanded to poison thee, at supper.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.p: At supper?

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: In the citadel.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.p: In the citadel.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Cross capers, tricks? truth a heaven would discharge us as boys do elder guns, one pellet to strike out another: of what faith art now?

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.p: All is damnation, wickedness extreme, there is no faith in man.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: In none but usurers and brokers, they deceive no man, men take 'em for bloodsuckers, and so they are: now God deliver me from my friends.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.p: Thy friends?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Yes, from my friends, for from mine enemies I'll deliver myself. O, cutthroat friendship is the rankest villainy, mark this Mendozo, mark him for a villain: but heaven will send a plague upon him for a rogue.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.p: O world!

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: World? 'tis the only region of death, the greatest shop of the devil, the cruelest prison of men, out of the which none pass without paying their dearest breath for a fee, there's nothing perfect in it, but extreme extreme calamity, such as comes yonder.

div.head: Scaena qvinta.
div.stage: Enter Aurelia, two holberts before, and two after, supported by Celso and Ferrard, Aurelia in base mourning attire.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: To banishment, led on to banishment ▪

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.p: Lady, the blessedness of repentance to you.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Why, why, I can desire nothing but death, nor deserve any thing but hell.

lg.l: If heaven should give sufficiency of grace
To dear my soul, it would make heaven graceless:
My sins would make the stock of mercy poor,
O they would try heaven's goodness to reclaim them:
Judgement is just yet from that vast villain:
But sure he shall not miss sad punishment,
For he shall rule on to my cell of shame.
My cell 'tis lady, where instead of masks,
Music, tilts, tournies, and such courtlike shows,
The hollow murmur of the checkless winds
Shall groan again, whilst the unquiet sea
Shakes the whole rock with foamy battery:
There usherless the air comes in and out,
The rheumy vault will force your eyes to weep,
Whilst you behold true desolation:
A rocky barrenness shall pain your eyes,
where all at once one reaches, where he stands,
With brows the roof, both walls with both his hands.
It is too good, blessed spirit of my lord:
Oh in what or before thy soul is throne,
Behold me worthily most miserable:
Oh let the anguish of my contrite spirit,
Entreat some reconciliation:
If not, oh joy! triumph in my just grief,
Death is the end of woes, and tears relief.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.p: Belike your lord not loved you, was unkind.

lg.l: O heaven,
As the soul loved the body, so loved he,
'Twas death to him to part my presence,
Heaven to see me pleased:
Yet I like to a wretch given o'er to hell,
Broke all the sacred rites of marriage,
To clip a base ungentle faithless villain:
Oh God, a very pagan reprobate!
What should I say, ungrateful throws me out,
For whom I lost soul, body, fame, and honour:
But 'tis most fit: why should a better fate
Attend on any, who forsake chaste sheets,
Fly the embrace of a devoted heart,
Joined by a solemn vow sore God and man,
To taste the brackish blood of beastly lust
In an adulterous touch? O ravenous immodesty,
Insatiate impudence of appetite:
Look, here's your end, for mark what sap in dust,
What sin in good, even so much love in lust:
Joy to thy ghost, sweet lord, pardon to me.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: It is the Duke's pleasure this night you rest in court.

lg.l: Soul lurk in shades, run shame from brightsome skies,
In night, the blind man misseth not his eyes.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Do not weep kind cuckold, take comfort man, thy betters have been beccos: Agamemnon emperor of all the merry Greeks; that tickled all the true Trojans, was a
cornuto: prince Arthur that cut off twelve Kings beards was a cornuto: Hercules, whose back, bore up heaven, and got forty wenches with child in one night.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.p: Nay 'twas fifty.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Faith forty's enough a conscience, yet was a cornuto: patience, mischief grows proud, be wise.

sp.speaker: Piet:
sp.p: Thou pinchest too deep, art too keen upon me.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Tut, a pitiful surgeon makes a dangerous sore. I'll tent thee to the ground. Thinkst I'll sustain myself by flattering thee, because thou art a prince? I had rather follow a drunkard, and live by licking up his vomit, than by servile flattery.

sp.speaker: Piet:
sp.p: Yet great men ha' don't.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Great slaves fear better than love, born naturally for a coal-basket, though the common usher of prince's presence fortune ha blindly given them better place, I am vowed to be thy affliction.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.p: Prithee be, I love much misery, and be thou son to me.

lg.l: Because you are an usurping Duke,
Your lordship's well returned for Florence. to Biliosa.

sp.speaker: Bil:
sp.p: Well returned, I praise my horse.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: What news from the Florentines?

sp.speaker: Bil:
sp.p: I will conceal the great Duke's pleasure, only this was his charge, his pleasure is, that his daughter die, Duke Pietro be banished for banishing his bloods dishonour, and that Duke Altofront be reaccepted: this is all, but I hear Duke Pietro is dead.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Ay, and Mendozo is Duke, what will you do?

sp.speaker: Bil:
sp.p: Is Mendozo strongest?

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Yet he is.

sp.speaker: Bil:
sp.p: Then yet I'll hold with him.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: But if that Altofront should turn straight again?

lg.l: Why then I would turn straight again:
'Tis good run still with him that has most might:
I had rather stand with wrong, then fall with right ▪

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Your lordship sweats, your young lady will get you a cloth for your old worship's brows,Exit Biliosa.here's a fellow to be damned, this is his inviolable Maximo. (Flatter the greatest, and oppress the least:) a whoreson flesh fly, that still gnaws upon the lean galled backs.

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: Why dust then salute him?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Faith as bawds go to church, for fashion's sake: come, be not confounded, thou'rt but in danger to 〈◊〉 a dukedom, think this: this earth is the only grave and Golgotha wherein all things that live must rotten: 'tis but the draught wherein the heavenly bodies discharge their corruption, the very muckhill on which the sublunary orbs cast their excrements: man is the slime of this dungpit, and princes are the governors of these men: for, for our souls, they are as free as emperors, all of one piece, there goes but a pair of shears betwixt an emperor and the son of a bagpiper: only the dying, dressing, pressing, glozing makes the difference: now what art thou like to lose?

lg.l: A jailor's office to keep men in bonds,
Whilst toil and treason, all life's good confounds.
I here renounce for ever regency,
Oh Altofront, I wrong thee to supplant thy right:
To trip thy heels up with a devilish slight.
For which I now from throne am thrown, world tricks abjure,
For vengeance that comes slow, yet it comes sure.
O I am changed, for herefore the dread power ▪
In true contrition I do dedicate,
My breath to solitary holiness,
My lips to prayer, and my breasts ear shall be,
Restoring Altofront to regency.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Thy vows are heard, and we accept thy faith.
sp.stage: Enter Ferneze and Celso undisguiseth himself.
sp.p: Altofront, Ferneze, Celso, Pietro.
Banish amazement: come, we four must stand full shock of fortune, be not so sunder strike.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.p: Doth Ferneze live?
For your pardon.

lg.l: Pardon and love, give leave to recollect
My thoughts dispersed in wild astonishment:
My vows stand fixed in heaven, and from hence
I crave all love and pardon.
Who doubts of providence,
T● 〈◊〉 this change, a hearty faith to all:
H● 〈◊〉 ●ust rise, who can no lower fall,
〈…〉 impetuous vicissitude
Loseth the world, then let no maze intrude
Upon your spirits: wonder not I rise,
For who can sink that close can temporise?
The time grows ripe for action, I'll detect
My privat'st plot, lest ignorance fear suspect:
Let's close to counsel, leave the rest to fate,
Mature discretion is the life of state.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Malevole and Maquarelle, at several doors opposite, singing.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: The Dutchman for a drunkard,

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: The Dane for golden locks:

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: The Irishman for usquebath,

sp.speaker: Maq
sp.p: The Frenchman for the ()

sp.speaker: Mal.
