sp.p: O thou art a blessed creature, had I a modest woman to conceal, I would put her to thy custody, for no reasonable creature would ever suspect her to be in thy company: ha, thou art a melodious Maquarelle, thou picture of a woman and substance of a beast, and how dost thou think a this transformation of state now?

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p:
Very very well, for we women always note, the falling of the one, is the rising of the other: some must be fat, some must be lean, some must be fools, and some must be lords: some must be knaves, and some must be
officers, some must be beggars, some must be knights ▪ some must be cuckolds , and some must be citizens: as for example, I have two court dogs, most fawning curs ▪ the one called watch, tother catch: now I, like lady fortune, sometimes love this dog ▪ sometimes rouse that dog, sometimes favour watch, most commonly fancy catch: now that dog which I favour I feed ▪ and he's so ravenous, that what I give he never chaws it, gulps it down 〈◊〉 without any relish of what he has, but with a great expectation of what he shall have: the other dog ▪ 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: No more dog, soot Maquarelle no more dog and what hope hast thou of the Duchess Maria, will she stoop to the Duke's luer, will she come, thinkst?

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Let me see where's the sign now? ha ye ere a calendar, where's the sign trow you?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Sign? why, is there any moment in that?

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: O believe me a most secret power, look ye a Caldean, or an Assyrian, I am sure was a most sweet Jew ●ould me, court any woman in the right sign, you shall not miss, but you must take her in the right vein then: as when the sign is in pisces, a fishmonger's wife is very sociable: in cancer, a precisian's wife is very flexible: in Capricorn, a merchant's wife hardly holds out: in Libra, a lawyer's wife is very tractable, especially, if her husband be at the term: only, in Scorpio's very dangerous meddling, has the Duke sent any jewel, any rich stones?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Ay, I think those are the best signs, to take a lady in: by your favour signeur: I must discourse with the lady Maria, Altofront's Duchess: I must enter for the Duke.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: She here shall give you interview, I received the guardship of this citadel from the good Altofront, and for his use I'll keep't, till I am of no use.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Wilt thou, oh heaven that a christian should be found in a buff-jerkin, captain conscience? I love thee
captain. Exit captain.we attend, and what hope hast thou of this Duchess easiness?

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: 'Twill go hard, she was a could creature ever, she hated monkeys, fools, jesters, and gentlemen ushers extremely: she had the vild trick on't, not only to be truly modestly honourable in her own conscience 〈◊〉 she would avoid the least wanton carriage 〈◊〉 might incur suspect, as God bless me, she 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 brought bed pressing out of fashion: I could scarce get a fine, for the lease of a lady's favour once in a fortnight.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Now in the name of immodesty, how many maidenheads hast thou brought to the block?

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Let me see: heaven forgive us our misdeeds, here's the Duchess.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: God bless thee lady,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Out of thy company:

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: We have brought thee tender of a husband,

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.p: I hope I have one already.

sp.speaker: M●q.
sp.p: Nay, by mine honour madam, as good he ne'er a husband, as a banished husband, he's in another world now, I'll tell the lady, I have heard of a sect that maintained, when the husband was asleep, the wife might lawfully entertain another man: for then her husband was as dead, much more when he is banished.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Unhonest creature:

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Pish, honesty is but an art to seem so: pray ye what's honesty? what's constancy? but fables feigned, odd old fools chat devised by jealous fools, to wrong our liberty.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Mully, he that loves thee is a Duke, Mendozo, he will maintain thee royally, love the ardently, defend thee powerfully, marry thee sumptuously, and keep thee in
despite of Rosiclere, or Donzell dell Phoebe's there's jewels, if thou wilt, so, if not, so.

lg.l: Captain, for god's love save poor wretchedness,
From tyranny of lustful insolence:
Enforce me in the deepest dungeon dwell
Rather than here, here round about is hell.
O my dearest Altofront where ere thou breath,
Let my soul sink into the shades beneath:
Before I stain thine honour, 'tis thou hast,
And long as I can die ▪ I will live chaste.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: 'Gainst him that can enforce how vain is strife?

lg.l: She that can be enforced has never a knife.
She that through force her limbs with lust enrols,
Wants Cleopatra's asps and Portia's coals.
God amend you.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: Now the fear of the devil for ever go with thee. Maquerelle, I tell thee I have found an honest woman, faith I perceive when all is done, there is of women as of all other things: some good, most bad, some saints, some sinners: for as now adays no courtier but has his mistress, no captain but has his cockatrice, no cuckold but has his horns, and no fool but has his father: even so no woman but has her weakness and feather too, no sex but has his: I can hunt the letter no further: oh God how loathsome this toying is to me, that a Duke should be forced to fool it: well, stultorumplena sunt omnia, better play the fool lord, then be the fool lord: now, where's your slights madam Maquarelle?

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Why, are ye ignorant that 'tis said, a squeamish affected niceness is natural to women, and that the excuse of their yielding, is only forsooth the difficult obtaining, you must put her to't, women are flax, and will fire in a moment.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Why was the flax put into thy mouth, and yet thou? thou set fire? thou inflame her.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Marry, but I'll tell ye now, you were too hot ▪

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: The fitter to have influenced the flaxwoman.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: You were too boisterous spleeny ▪ for indeed.

sp.speaker: Mr

lg.l: 〈◊〉, thou art a weak panderess, now I see.
Sooner earth's fire heaven itself shall waste,
Than all with her can melt a mind that's chaste.

sp.p: Go thou the Duke's lime-twig, I'll make the Duke turn thee out of thine office, what not get one touch of hope, and 〈◊〉 at such advantage.
Now a my conscience, now I think in my discreet 〈◊〉 did not take her in ●e ●ght sign, the blood was not in the true vein, sure.

div.head: Scaena Tertia.
div.stage: Enter Prepasso and Ferrand, 〈◊〉 with lights, Celso and Equato, Mendozo in darker robes, Bilioso and Guerrino. : exeunt all saving: Malevole.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: On on, leave us, leave us 〈◊〉 where is the hermit ▪

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: With Duke Pietro, with Duke Pietro.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Is he dead? is he poisoned ▪

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Dead as the Duke is.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Good, excellent, he will not blab ▪ secureness lives in secrecy ▪ come hither ▪ come hither.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Thou hast a certain strong villainous sent about thee, my nature cannot indu.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Sent man? what returns Maria? what answer to our suit?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Cold ▪ frosty, she is obstinate.

lg.l: Then she's but dead 'tis resolute, she dies:
Black deed only through black deeds safely flies ▪

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Pew, per scelera semper sceleribus tutum est iter.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: What art a scholar? art a politician? sure thou art an errand knave.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Wh● I? I h● been twice an under sheriff, man.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Canst thou empoison ▪ canst thou impoison?

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p:
Excellently ▪ no Jew ▪ pothecary, or politician better: look ye, here's a box, whom wouldst thou impoison, here's a box, which opened, and the fume ●ne up in condites, thorough which the brain purges itself, doth instantly for 12. hours space, bind up all show of life in a deep senseless sleep:
here's another, which being opened under the sleepers nose, chokes all the pores of life, kills him suddenly.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I'll try experiments, 'tis good not to be decoved ▪ 〈◊〉 so, Catzo:

lg.l: Who would fear that ma destroy, death hath no teeth, nor tongue,seems to poison Malevole.
And he that's great ▪ to him one slaves shame,
Murder, fame and wrong ▪ Celzo?

sp.speaker: Cell:
sp.p: My honoured lord.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: The good Malevole, that plain-tongued 〈◊〉, is dead on sudden wondrous strangely, he held in our esteem good place,
Celso, see him buried, see him buried.

sp.speaker: Cels:
sp.p: I shall observe ye.

lg.l: And Celso, 〈◊〉 let it be thy care tonight
To have some pretty show ▪ to solemnize
Our high instalment, some music, maskery:
We'll give fair entertain unto Maria
The Duchess to the banished Altofront:
Thou shalt conduct her from the citadel
Unto the palace, think on some maskery.

sp.speaker: Cel:
sp.p: Of what shape, sweet lord,

sp.speaker: Men.

lg.l: Why shape? why any quick done fiction,
As some brave spirits of the Genoan Dukes,
To come out of Elysium forsooth,
Led in by Mercury to gratulate

sp.p: Our happy fortune, some such any thing, some far fet trick, good for ladies, some stale toy or other, no matter so't be of our devising.

lg.l: Do thou prepar't, 'tis but for fashion's sake,
Fear not, it shall be graced man, it shall take.

sp.speaker: Cel:
sp.p: All service.

lg.l: All thanks, our hand shall not be close to thee: farewell
Now is my treachery secure, nor can we fall:
Mischief that prospers men do virtue call,
I'll trust no man, he that by tricks ▪ go●s wreathes,
Keeps them with ●le, no man seemely breathes,
Out of 〈◊〉 ranks the crowd will mutter fool:
Who cannot bear with spite he cannot rule:
the chiefest secret for a man of state,
Is to live senseless of a strengthless hate.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Death of the damned thief, I'll make one i'the mask, thou shalt ha' some
Brave spirits of the antique Dukes.

sp.speaker: Cel:
sp.p: My lord, what strange delusion?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Most happy, dear Celso, poisoned with an emptystarts up and speaks. box ▪ I'll give thee all anon: my lady comes to court, there is whirl of fate comes tumbling on ▪ the castle's captain stands for me, the people pray for me, and the great leader of the just stands for me: then courage Celso.

lg.l: For no disastrous chance can ever m●e him,
That leaveth nothing but a god above him.

div.stage: Enter Prepasso and Bilioso, two pages, before them Maquar: Beanche, and Emilia.

sp.speaker: Bil:
sp.p: Make room there, room for the ladies: why gentlemen, will not ye suffer the ladies to be entered in the great chamber? why gallants? and you sir, to drop your torch where the beauties must sit too.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.p: And there's a great fellow plays the knave, why dost not strike him?

sp.speaker: Bil:
sp.p: Let him play the knave a god's name, thinkst thou I have no more wit than to strike a great fellow, the music, more lights, revelling, scaffolds: do you hear? let there be oaths enough ready at the door, swear out the devil himself. Let's leave the ladies, and go see if the lords be ready for them.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: And by my troth beauties, why do you not put you into the fashion, this is a stale cut ▪ you must come in fashion: look ye, you must be all felt, felt and feather, a felt upon your head: look ye, these ●ing things are justly out of request now: and do ye hear? you must wear falling bands, you must come into the falling fashion: there is such a deal a pinning these ruffs, when the fine clean fall is worth all: and again ▪ if you should chance to take a nap in the afternoon, your falling ba● requires no poting stick to recover his form: beheve me, no fashion to the falling band I say.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: And is not 〈◊〉 s. Andrew Iaques gallant fellow now?

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: By my maidenhead la, honour and he agrees as well together, as a satin suit and woollen stockings.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: But, is not martial Make-room my servant in reversion, a proper gentleman?

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: Yes in reversion as he had his office, as in truth he hath all things in reversion: he has his mistress in reversion, his clothes in reversion, his wit in reversion, and indeed, is a suitor to me for my dog in reversion: but in good verity la, he is as proper a gentleman in reversion as: and indeed, as fine a man as may be, having a red beard and a pair of warped legs,

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: But i'faith I am most monstrously in love with count quidlibet in quodlibet, is he not a pretty dapper windle gallant?

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: He is even one of the most busy fingered lords, he will put the beauties to the squeak most hideously.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Room, make a lane there, the Duke is entering: stand handsomely for beauty's sake, take up the ladies there. So, cornets, cornets.

div.head: Scaena qvarta.
div.stage: Enter Prepasso joins to Bilioso ▪ two pages with lights, Ferrard, Mendozo, at the other door two pages with lights, and the captain leading in Maria, the Duke meets Maria, a● closeth with her, the rest fall back.

lg.l: Madam, with gentle ear receive my suit,
A kingdom's safety should o'er poise slight rites,
Marriage is merely nature's policy:
Then since unless our royal beds be joined,
Danger and civil tumult frights the state,
Be wise as you are fair, give way to fa●.

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.p: What wouldst thou, thou affliction to our house? Thou ever devil, 'twas thou that banishedst my truly noble lord.

sp.speaker: Men ▪
sp.p: I?

lg.l: Ay, by the plots by thy black stratagems,
Twelve moons have suffered change since I beholded
the loved presence of my dearest lord.
O thou fair worse than death, he parts but soul
From a weak body, but thou soul from soul
Dissever'st, that which gods own hand did knit.
Thou scant of honour, full of devilish wit.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.p: We'll check your too intemperate lavishness, I I can, and will.

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.p: What canst?

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.p: Go to, in banishment thy husband dies.

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.p: He ever is at home that's ever wise.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Youst never meet more reason should love control,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Not meet?
She that dear loves, her love's still in her soul.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: You are but a woman lady, you must yield.

lg.l: O save me thou innated bashfulness,
Thou only ornament of woman's modesty.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.p: Modesty? Death I'll torment thee,

lg.l: Do, urge all torments, all afflictions try,
I'll die, my lords, as long as I can die.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.p: Thou obstinate, thou shalt die: captain, that lady's life is forfeited to justice, we have examined her,

lg.l: And we do find, she hath empoisoned
The reverend hermit, therefore we command
Severest custody. Nay, if you'll does no good,
Youst does no harm, a tyrant's peace is blood.
O thou art merciful, oh gracious devil,
Rather by much let me condemned be,
For seeming murder than be damned for thee.
I'll mourn no more, come girt my brows with flowers,
Revel and dance, soul, now thy wish thou hast,
Die like a bride, poor heart thou shalt die chaste. Enter Aurelia in mourning habit.
Life is a frost of could felicity,
And death the thaw of all our vanity.
Wast not an honest priest that wrote so?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Who? let her in.

sp.speaker: Bili.
sp.p: Forbear.

sp.speaker: P●..
sp.p: Forbear.

lg.l: Alas calamity is 〈◊〉 where.
Sad misery, despite your double doors ▪
Will enter even in court.

sp.speaker: Bili.
sp.p: Peace.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I ha' done; one word, take heed, I ha' done.

div.stage: Enter mercurio with lords d● music.

lg.l: Cilleman Merc●, the god of ghosts,
From gloomy shades that spread the lower coasts,
Calls four high famed Genoa Dukes to come,
And make this presence their Elysium:
To pass away this high triumphal night,
With song and dances, courts more soft delight.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Are you god of ghosts, I have a suit depending in hell betwixt me and my conscience, I would fain have thee help me to an advocate.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Mercury shall be your lawyer lady,

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Nay faith, Mercury has too good a face to be a right lawyer.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.p: Peace, forbear: Mercury presents the mask.

div.stage: Cornets: the song to the cornets, which playing the mask enters.
Enter Malevole, Pietro, Ferneze, and Celso in white robes, with Duke's crowns upon laurel, wreathes, pistolets and short swords under their robes.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Celso, Celso, court Maria for our love lady, be gracious, yet grace.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: With me sir?

lg.l: Yes more loved than my breath:Malevole takes his wife to dance.
With you I'll dance.
Why then you dance with death,
But come sir, I was ne'er more apt for mirth.
Death gives eternity a glorious breath
Oh, to die honoured, who would fear to die.

sp.speaker: Mal:
sp.p: They die in fear who live in villainy.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Yes, believe him lady, and be ruled by him.

sp.speaker: Pietro,
sp.p: Madam with me? Pietro takes his wife Au●ia to dance

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Wouldst then be miserable?

sp.speaker: Pietro,
sp.p: I need not wish.

lg.l: O, yet forbear my hand, away, fly, fly,
oh seek not her that only seeks to ●y.

sp.speaker: Pietro,
sp.p: Poor loved soul.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: What, wouldst court misery?

sp.speaker: Pietro,
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: She'll come too soon oh my grieved heart.

lg.l: Lady ha' done, ha, done.
Come down let's dance, be once from sorrow free.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Art a sad man?

sp.speaker: Pietro,
sp.p: Yes sweet.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Then we'll agree.

div.stage: Ferneze takes Maquerelle, and Celso Beanche: then the cornets sound the measure, on change, and rest.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: Believe it lady, shall I swear, let me enjoy you into Beancha. private, and I'll marry you by my soul.

sp.speaker: Bean.
sp.p: I had rather you would swear by your body: I think that would prove the more regarded oath with you.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: I'll swear by them both, to please you.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: O ▪ dam them not both, to please me, for god's sake.

sp.speaker: Eer.
sp.p: Faith sweet creature let me enjoy you tonight , and I'll marry you tomorrow fortnight, by my troth lo.

sp.speaker: Maq.
sp.p: On his troth lo, believe him not, that kind of coney-catching is as stale as fir Oliver anchoves perfumed jerkin: promise of matrimony by a young gallant, to bring a virgin lady into a fool's paradise: make her a great woman, and then cast her off: 'tis as common as natural to a courtier, as jealousy to a citizen, gluttony to a Puritan, wisdom to an alderman, pride to a tailor, or an empty to one of these sixpenny damnations: of his troth lo, believe him not, traps to catch polecats.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Keep your face constant, let no sudden passion speak in your eyes. to Maria.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O my Altofront.

sp.speaker: Pietro
sp.p: A tyrant's jealousies are very nimble, you receive it all. to Aurelia.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: My heart though not my knees doth humbly fall, lo as the earth to thee.

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.p: Peace, next change, no words.

div.stage: Cornets sound the measure 〈◊〉 against which 〈◊〉 they 〈◊〉 ▪

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Malevole ▪

div.stage: They environ Mendozo loading their pistols on him.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Altofront, Duke Lorenzo Fer●, hah?

sp.speaker: All,
sp.p: Duke Altofront, Duke Altofront.

lg.l: Are we surprised? what strange delusions ocke
Our senses, do I dream? or have I dream●
This two days' space? where am I?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Where an arch villain is.

lg.l: O lend me breath to live till I am fit to die.
For peace with heaven, for your own soul's sake
Vouchsafe me life.

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.p: Ignoble villain, whom neither heaven nor hell, goodness of God or man could once make good.

lg.l: Base treacherous wretch, what grace canst thou expect,
That hast grown impudent in gracelessness.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: O life!

lg.l: Slave, take thy life.
Wert thou defenced through blood and wounds,
The sternest horror of a civil fight,
Would I achieve thee, but prostrate at my feet,
I scorn to hurt thee, 'tis the heart of slaves
That deigns to triumph over peasant's graves.
For such thou art since 〈◊〉 d● 〈◊〉 〈◊〉
A man 'mong monarchs, but a glorious soul ▪to Pietro and Aurelia. To Mendozo to Maquerel: to Bilioso. To Celso and the captain: to Maria.
You are joyed spirits, wipe your long ●et 〈◊〉. Malevole kicks out Mendozo.
Hence with this man: an eagle takes not flies.
You to your vows to Pietro and Aurelia, and thou unto the 〈◊〉.
You to my worst friend I would 〈◊〉 give:
Thou art a perfect old knave all pleased live ▪
You two unto my breast, thou to my heart ▪
And as for me I here assume my right,
To which I hope all's pleased: to all god night.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
